Hello and welcome everyone. I'm Corey

Models, the podcast that pulls back the

Cory Hoffstein is the co-founder and

My guest this episode is Benjamin Hoff,
global head of commodity strategy at
Sockgen. In this conversation, we
explore how commodities differ
fundamentally from other asset classes,
the importance of cash and carry
economics, the sparse information
cadence that rewards technical models,
and the physical realities that
challenge purely quantitative
approaches. We also dive into Ben's more
recent work on the geometry of the
future surface, how convexity and
skewess may be misunderstood, and why
tools like levy area may help undercover
nonlinear structure in the data. Whether
you're deep in the weeds of term
structure trading or just curious about
how to systematize chaos in barrels and
bushels, this is a conversation you
won't want to miss. Please enjoy my
conversation with Benjamin Hoff.
[Music]
Ben, welcome to the show. Very excited
to have you here and talk about all
about commodities. I feel like it's
pretty rare that I get a real commodity

commodity strategy specialist. So, thank
you for joining me. Really looking

forward to the conversation.
 Same here,
Corey. Thank you so much for having me

on.
 So, I know you didn't begin your

 Absolutely. It

designed to rotate people around

 You

Can you talk a little bit about what

 You bring up

And I think it's something that a lot of

 Yeah, exactly. I
mean, I think that's actually a

there. So, absolutely. I mean, you know,
I'm not going to waxical about an asset
class like rates that I know
significantly less about than I know
about commodities.
Truly when you look at what determines
price formation along the crude oil term
structure just to use that as an example
it is really cash and carry dynamics
that form to force first order at least
the connection point between the
deferred points on the term structure

by that is when you think about it well
why would a December contract include be
tied to a July contract? Well, the

in a normally functioning world, and I

is, is there physical storage available?
I mean, it's all great. You can have all
the credit in the world and at least
hypothetically be able to buy as many
barrels as you like on credit, but
unless you can store those barrels and
store them in the right location, I
think that's the other important
ingredient here. It's just a pure
theoretical exercise and there is no
real reason then if you can't find
storage for that December barrel to in
any way be tied to the July barrel and
so absent those two things you end up in
a world where the curve structure the
term structure ultimately starts looking
really quite brittle in commodity this
is real this isn't something that just
happens once in a while when the world
is falling apart when some kind of
arcane corner case this is real and you
think about natural gas you know natural
Gas is the archetypal example of a
highly seasonal commodity where
basically the North American the
northern hemisphere winter ends
typically in March and it's basically a

keep on drawing from storage and the
fear that the market has is that we will
end winter in a situation where there's
not enough left in quote unquote the
tank where we just run out and that is
what's reflected in the curve. So what
ends up happening is when you look at
what that actually means, it means that
there's a very natural dislocation that
exists particularly at the beginning of
winter between the March contract and
subsequent experies just because it
could very well be the case that at the
end of winter there is nothing left to
cash and carry over to the next season.
So these things are real and it's not
just natural gas, right? It's corn, it's
wheat, it's beans, it's anything that's
on a seasonal production pattern with
constant demand, which is basically the

deeply inherent to commodities and
uniquely inherent to commodities. One of
the key differences you highlighted
about the commodities market in our

out for commodities that there's very
little fundamental news flow in
commodities and you were of the view
that this made it a fertile ground for

statistical models. I was hoping you
could talk a little bit about this

the fundamental sources of news, whether

or satellite crop imagery, for example.
And how should systematic traders think
about balancing some of these slower
moving more sparse fundamental signals
versus the faster technical signals that
left to run alone could just become sort
of wild feedback loops in the market if
they are untethered from the

fundamentals.
 Yeah, I mean I think
context here is everything and I mean
you bring up a really good point. It's
something that I think is really quite
differentiating again for commodities
versus other asset classes in particular
rates and FX but also equities. I mean
just bear in mind you know when you look
at the grains you basically have a
monthly was report then depending on the

report that comes out weekly and then
you've got the big nothingness of winter
where basically nothing is happening. So
that's very very different to pretty
much every other asset class under the
sun. You look at rates, I mean there's
not a week that goes by where there
isn't some not just one but multiple
pieces of macro news flow which
inherently have the ability to affect a
fundamental repricing of the term
structure. Pretty much everything
affects equities. Not just company
specific news but all the macro news
that you have in rates feeds into
equities as well. That is marketly
different to commodities. So then the
question really becomes well what does a
market like corn trade on when there's a
sparseness of fundamental news flow. So
absent fundamental news flow what are
you going to trade on other than
technical or at least apparently
technical news flow. Now I say
apparently because obviously the USDA is
not the only propagator of fundamental
information in grains markets and this
sort of ties back to your point
satellite imagery real time weather data
these are all obviously things that are
available but the point that I think is
really quite important to make here is
that they're not necessarily
cross-sectionally available by the same
vendor using exactly the same data
collection methods published at exactly
the same time across 20 plus markets. So
what ends up happening is that price
really ends up being the equilibrator
there. Right? So the way I look at the
world is that a lot of this information
ultimately gets factored into pricing
and pricing ultimately ends up sort of
providing this in a way where it's
available cross-sectionally in some kind
of transformed way. this information
cross-sectionally pretty much at the
same time up to slight lags in closing
time. And it's that perspective where
you can kind of see that complete
deteathering and kind of closed circuit
price formation just on technicals isn't
exactly what we're dealing with. What I
will say is not just sort of completely
denigrate the role of fundamentals, but
I look at fundamentals a little bit more
as a way of categorizing market regimes
in many ways. and you're really
providing the backdrop for technical
signals. And that is I think one really
good way of using the slower moving and
sometimes and often times actually
market specific slower moving

fundamental news flow.
 I want to talk
about what happens when these markets
become untethered because in the last 5
years we've lived through what we would
probably consider to be two super
contango episodes with WTI crude in

little bit about operationally what has

Yeah, look I mean I think crude going
negative to the tune of $37 and change
in April 2020. Can't remember the exact
date. I mean that is clearly not what
was intended or what is typical in these
markets. So what went wrong? Well 2020 I
guess tested a lot of different
financial markets to the limits. And I
think one thing really worth bearing in
mind when it comes to commodities is
that commodities per se, commodity
futures markets broadly and there are
exceptions but broadly are not only
financial markets, right? They have a
physical mechanism that basically allows
the futures contract to expire into
something that requires the making or
taking of physical delivery of some
commodity. And so in that way when I
look at commodity futures markets and I
contrast them with rates futures
markets, bond futures markets, there's
an added layer of complexity there and
as a result an added layer of
vulnerability under market stress. So
when you're in this situation where
basically you've got a liquidity
squeeze, you have physical dislocations
and the two happen at exactly the same
time. to kind of bring up the example of
crude then absolutely you can end up
with some fairly unexpected side effects
such as negative pricing that should and
is not the normal state of the world but
it is just something worth bearing in
mind and it comes back to what I was
saying initially in a very easy in a
normal world to look at a barrel of
crude and the price of a barrel of crude
the same way as you look at a stock
price the truth of the matter is that
the underlying financial instrument
really is very very different here and
that added layer of granularity of being
able to make and take physical delivery
is crucial to these markets, crucial to
their survival. That's why they exist. I
mean, commodity futures markets do not
exist for financial investors in the
last analysis. Commodity futures markets
exist to facilitate risk transformation
for physical hedges. So when you think
of a barrel of crude oil, the thing has
on a good day an inherent volatility in
the spot market somewhere on the order
of 30 to 40 vols. If you're in the
physical market, you're either a
consumer or a producer. That's a pretty
significant value at risk to be carrying
on your balance sheet.
The role that commodity futures markets
have is to allow the transformation of
that directional risk into a time spread
risk by allowing a producer to short
futures against the physical barrel. And
in doing so, you end up dropping the
native volatility of the combination of
the spot instrument and the futures
instrument by an order of magnitude
pretty much. So that is why these
markets exist. financial investors.
They're great to have. We love them in
the marketplace, but they are not the
primary economic reason why these
markets are around. That's one crucial
difference with financial markets. So
before we start talking about different
commodity strategies, which is where
we're going to spend the majority of the
time of this episode, I want to pose to
you maybe what is a little bit of an
unfair question, but it's one that comes

exposure is marketed as having this idea

of markets that investors can actually
harvest by simply being long

I'm curious as someone who has studied
these markets for as long as you have,
where do you come down? Is there a
positive expected risk premium that can
be harvested just by being netlong
commodities? Yeah, I mean I think that's
a really good question, Corey, and I'd
probably need to sit here and scratch my
head a little bit about exactly the
right way to answer, but my sense is
that there's a little bit of a nuance or
difference between the academic and the

only commodity exposure, typically who

who are looking to hedge something,
right? What they're looking to hedge is

context of your optimization function
being to hedge unexpected inflation, it
definitely seems the case that
commodities have sort of lived up to

context of a long only commodity

which I'm sure we'll come to talk about

this is the first time I'd ever read
something like this. I thought it was
really unique. What do you think that
this lens, this approach of thinking of
different investment styles via
derivatives of this surface? What does
that reveal that maybe some single
factor studies where you're looking at
these things truly as isolation and not

object? What are those single factor

provides you? Well, probably the most
important aspect for me when I look at
what generates commodity alpha in
general is what is the economic
principle behind what we're trying to do
here. And you know that was very much
the inspiration of this paper as well.
So when I look at what is likely to
persist when you've got a any alter
signal commodities or elsewhere doesn't
really matter. You really care about two
things. One is the strength of your
signal and the other is how long is the
signal likely to persist for. And you
really want to have a combination of
both because a strong signal basically
kind of means that you're more likely to
hit your target. Persistence ultimately
means that you're in a world where
you're not just flipping around
perpetually. And so when you think about
this whole idea of effectively fitting
if you like a tangent space to the
surface that's made up out of one
dimension being time to expert in the
other dimension being time. You can kind
of see that what we're trying to do here
is really just capture the fact that
hopefully that tangent space is going to
be slower moving than the thing we're
effectively approximating. And that's
something that's quite common in
mathematics. I mean, you know, that's
why people look at derivatives of curves
that's up to some order because they
don't necessarily care about the super
fine structure that's captured, you
know, five orders down the tailor
expansion. They're good enough just
knowing, you know, what is the first
order and maybe the second order
derivative. And so the approach here is
effectively to say, look, it's the first
and second order derivative that
actually have meaningful economics
associated to them and they're cross
derivatives. So the derivative with
respect to time, the second derivative
with respect to time, the derivative
with respect to time to expiry, the
second derivative with respect to time
to expiry, which is effectively the
convexity with crucial for carry
strategies, and then the cross
derivatives and so that's really where
we were coming from there is to
basically say look where is the
persistency likely to be. Truth be told,
this comes back to where we were a
couple of minutes ago. Commodity markets
ultimately are designed for physical
hedges. And physical hedges, they can't
afford to operate in a world where the
curved surface is effectively snapping
around in a completely random way every
day, right? That just does not allow for
rationally based hedging decisions that
can persist through time. And that's
ultimately what they're after. So you
can kind of sort of see which came
first, which came second. probably a
little bit like chicken and egg. But the
truth is you cannot have dynamics which
are completely random when it comes to
the actual curve dynamics that are
captured by these derivatives. And just
for sort of completeness to make sure
everyone's on the same page as we're
talking about this, can you walk through
each of the derivatives and how it links
to maybe what already exists in the
literature as one of the style premium
or whether it represents maybe a unique

factor?
 Yeah. And absolutely. So look,
you know, first of all, I'll just
preface it with the fact that it's not a
panacea. You cannot recover every single
commodity QIS style with this approach.
But the styles that you can recover, the
first derivative with respect to time, I
mean, is basically uh trend. The second
derivative with respect to time still
kind of some version of trend. You can
maybe call it trend of trend. Then you
start moving on to derivatives with
respect to time to exper. I mean a
strategy that's been out there for a
long time now is something that's often
labeled as backquidation momentum which
is effectively ranking of a portfolio of
commodities according to the slope of
their term structure where the idea is
to go long the markets that are most
backquidated. So where the front of the
curve is pricing at the strongest
premium relative to the back of the
curve and short the markets where you've
got the exact opposite where the front
of the curve is pricing at a discount to
the back of the curve. So that's
something that pretty much linearly maps
to the turf first derivative of the
surface with respect to time to x3. The
second derivative with respect to time
to x3 is really convexity. Convexity is
a crucial driver in carry strategies.
You know, when you think about commodity
carry, what's the idea? Well, the idea
is to be short the front of the term
structure and long the back of the term
structure. Now, if you've got a
perfectly linear curve, and I would say
gold is a good example of this most of
the time where effectively gold
basically just prices on a carry basis
that's relative comparative to the value
of an ounce of gold. the storage of gold
is dimminimous. The insurance costs are
relatively small. So what you end up
with is effectively this financing cost
which is just linear in the cost of
gold. So gold effectively is an example
of a market where being short the front
of the curve and long the back of the
curve could theoretically generate you
really nice sharp ratios but almost no
returns because rolling down the front
of the curve at exactly the same rate
and making money because you're short as
you're losing money on the back of the
curve where you're rolling down as well
at exactly the same rate but in that
instance you're long. So that's not a
good example. But other markets like
crude, like natural gas, you've got this
situation where there's negative
convexity in your term structure where
basically if the curve shape doesn't
change and it stays exactly like it is
today and the only change is really the
fact that time keeps marching forward,
then what happens is that due to the
negative convexity, you're rolling down
at a slower rate in the back where you
long than you're rolling down in the
front where you short. And because
you're rolling down at a higher quote
unquote speed in the front, you end up
making more money on the short side than
you're losing on the long side. So this
notion of convexity absolutely crucial
in carry also because it's relatively
slower moving. Now it's obviously not
the say only driver of a carry strategy
because carry strategies obviously have
sensitivity to changes in slope. But
changes in slope. This basically comes
to the next value style that's
incorporated in this curved derivative
framework which is basis momentum.
Right? So basis momentum the idea
broadly behind basis momentum is to ask
how is the slope of the curve changing
through time. If I've got a positive
change of slope through time, I probably
want to be going long because the curve
is steepening. And I've got a negative
change in slope through time. I want to
probably be going short because the
curve shape is weakening. So again,
you've got sort of the final version
there of QIS strategies that are
encapsulated. Now what's interesting,
Cory, is that there's clearly a limit to
this, right? You could keep on playing
this game of effectively having higher
and higher tailor order expansions, but
I touched on this briefly in one of the
previous questions where we talked about
how producers and consumers can
transform their flat price risk into
spread risk by trading futures against
their physical position. And in so
doing, their advantage to them is that
they end up reducing the volatility by
an order of magnitude. Now, what we've
just been talking about is kind of
similar, right? If you wanted to, you
could probably play this game of
expanding your curve approximation to
higher order derivatives. But the
problem is if you really want to capture
the third order derivative, you need to
be trading spreads of spreads. So, two
spreads on the same curve. And in so
doing, you've effectively just dropped
your volatility by another order of
magnitude. And so you get to this point
where it just basically ends up being a
negative tradeoff between the alpha you
could theoretically harvest and the
transaction costs that you're incurring
to do so where basically the alpha that
you're trying to capture just does not
have inherently enough volatility to
justify that. So that's why most people
us included would typically say second
order is as far as any reasonable person
can possibly go. I want to go back to
the point you were making about carry
strategies because carry strategies are
a very common place in commodities
especially commodity QIS and you wrote a
paper in 2024 titled all you ever wanted
to know about commodity carry and you
highlighted in that paper this idea that
traditional carry includes significant
exposure to this second order term
structure convexity and it's not just
sort of this linear ro yield concept.
And so for people who are hearing this
for the first time, right, who maybe
haven't thought through the world via
this surface idea, this sort of second
order derivative and what that convexity
means. How should allocators to
commodity carry or people who are
designing commodity carry strategies
reinterpret classic carry metrics in
light of this convexity? How should they
be rethinking about what this convexity
component of returns implies for what
carry is ultimately pricing and the

risks embedded in carry styles.
 It's a
really interesting one because I find
the whole convexity notion actually
allows you to articulate in very clear
intuitive economic words what
specifically the risk premium is that
you're trying to capture. When you think
about commodity carry strategies, I mean
you can do a PCA of any principal
component analysis of any commodity term
structure and you'll find that well the
first three principal components are
really dominant. The first one is
basically just the level price
movements. The second one is changes in
slope and the third one is basically the
convexity piece. And when you look at
the first two, they basically are highly
subject to exogenous shocks. The third
one, the convexity piece is actually
much more about the micro supply chain
of an individual market. And so just
take crude oil as an example, just
because it's June 23rd, it's topical. We
